SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, one of the oldest inhabited areas in the US, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. The adjacent portion of the river provides water to many people in New Mexico. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in New Mexico provides water to many people and is a critical habitat for endangered species. The Corps of Engineers aims to maintain the bosque while making it more accessible to the public and reestablishing hydrologic connections for healthy vegetation growth. The Middle Rio Grande bosque in New Mexico supports healthy growth of native vegetation. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Critical restoration project: Immediate and substantial ecosystem restoration, preservation, recreation, and protection benefits.
(2) Middle Rio Grande: Portion of the Rio Grande from Cochiti Dam to Elephant Butte Dam in New Mexico.
(3) Secretary: Secretary of the Army.

SEC. 3. MIDDLE RIO GRANDE RESTORATION. The Secretary will conduct critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting projects based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing studies and plans. Local participation is required in carrying out the Act. The Secretary will consult with public and private entities active in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed, including the Middle Rio Grande Endangered Species Act Collaborative Program and the Bosque Improvement Group of the Middle Rio Grande Bosque Initiative. Cost-sharing agreements with non-Federal interests are required before critical restoration projects are carried out under this Act. Non-Federal interests must enter into an agreement to pay 25% of total costs, provide necessary resources, and cover all future operation and maintenance costs for critical restoration projects. The critical restoration project must hold the United States harmless from any claims or damages, excluding negligence, and recreational features should not exceed 30% of the total project cost. The non-Federal interests must cover any recreational features exceeding 30% of the total project cost. They can receive credit for work done before the project agreement is executed. Non-Federal interests must cover recreational features exceeding 30% of the total project cost and can receive credit for work done before the project agreement is executed. The Secretary may determine that work performed by the non-Federal interest is integral to the project. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
